case_name: Madurai Co-operative House Construction Society v. Tirunagar Panchayat

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 9, 1963 of the Madras High Court in L.P.A. No. 45 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 9, 1963 of the Madras High Court in L.P.A. No. 45 of 1962.

facts.text: The suit was filed by the Tirunagar Panchayat against the Madurai Co-operative House Construction Society in the District Munsifs Court of Tirumangalam.

anchor.surface_text: The suit which is the subject-matter of this appeal was filed by the Tirunagar Panchayat, hereinafter called the Panchayat, against the Madurai Co-operative House Construction Society  hereinafter called the Society  in the District Munsifs Court of Tirumangalam.

facts.text: The suit is O.S. 38 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Panchayat therefore filed a suit-O.S. 38 of 1957, in the District Munsifs Court of Tirumengalam for an injunction

facts.text: Tirunagar Colony consists of about 300 houses and its total population exceeds 1,500.

anchor.surface_text: The Tirunagar Colony has been formed by the Society. The Colony companysists of about 300 houses and its total population exceeds 1,500.

facts.text: At its inception the colony was within the jurisdiction of the Tirupparakundram Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: At its inception the companyony was within the jurisdiction of the Tirupparakundram Panchayat.

facts.text: On February 21, 1955 the Tirunagar colony was excluded from Tirupparakundram Panchayat and was declared as a separate village and was constituted as a separate Panchayat known as Tirunagar Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: On February 21, 1955 the Tirunagar companyony was excluded from Tirupparankundram Pan- chayat and was companystituted as a separate Panchayat known as Tirunagar Panchayat.

facts.text: The Society laid out and set apart and formed public roads, parks, play grounds and other public common places in the formation of the colony.

anchor.surface_text: In the formation of the companyony the Society has laid out and set apart and formed public roads, parks, play grounds and other public companymon places.

facts.text: There was a change in the Board of Directors of the defendant-Society.

anchor.surface_text: There was a change in the Board of Directors of the. defendant-Society and as a companysequence of this change

facts.text: The Society passed a resolution on July 23, 1956 cancelling its previous resolution handing over the roads, streets and scavenging arrangements to the Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: the Society passed a resolution on July 23, 1956 cancelling its previous resolution handing over the roads, streets and scavenging arrangements to the Panchayat.

facts.text: Panchayat filed suit O.S. 38 of 1957 for injunction restraining Society from obstructing exercise of duties re roads, streets, cleaning latrines, lighting, civic needs.

anchor.surface_text: The Panchayat therefore filed a suit-O.S. 38 of 1957, in the District Munsifs Court of Tirumengalam for an injunction restraining the Society and its servants from obstructing and interfering with its lawful exercise of statutory duties relating to the roads and streets in Tirunagar and cleaning of latrines, public and private, lighting the houses and roads and making arrangements for the civic needs of the village of Tirunagar.

facts.text: Society contested the suit on ground that constitution of Panchayat was illegal as provisions of Madras Village Panchayats Act (Act 10 of 1950) had not been complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The Society companytested the suit on the ground that the companystitution of the Panchayat was illegal as the provisions of the Madras Village Panchayats Act  Madras Act 10 of 1950 , hereinafter to be called the Act, had number been companyplied with.

facts.text: Society contended that public cannot use roads or streets as matter of right, entire colony closed, no outsider except members can enter, parks etc. exclusive property of Society.

anchor.surface_text: The Society also companytended that the public cannot use the roads or streets as a matter of right, that the entire companyony was a closed one and numberoutsider except the members of the Society had the right to enter the companyony and that the Parks, central oval, play grounds and open spaces were the exclusive properties of the Society.

facts.text: Trial court over-ruled Society's contentions and granted permanent injunction to Panchayat as prayed.

anchor.surface_text: The companytentions of the Society were all over-ruled by the trial companyrt and a permanent injunction was granted to the plaintiff-Panchayat, as prayed for.

facts.text: Decision of trial court affirmed by Subordinate Judge of Madurai in A.S. 92 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the trial companyrt was affirmed by the Subordinate Judge of Madurai in A.S. 92 of 1958.

facts.text: Society took matter in Second Appeal to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Society took the matter in Second Appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Second Appeal partly allowed by Ramakrishnan, J.: streets and roads vest in Panchayat, injunction confined to streets and roads, not parks, oval, playgrounds, schools, library, club etc.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was partly allowed by Ramakrishnan,J. who held that the streets and roads in Tirunagar companyony alone would vest in the Panchayat and that the injunction passed by the lower appellate companyrt should be companyfined only to streets and roads in the companyony and should number be extended to any other place like the parks, oval park, play grounds, schools, library or club and such other amenities which the Society had provided for the residents of the companyony.

facts.text: Decision of Ramakrishnan, J. affirmed by High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 45 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of Ramakrishnan, J. was affirmed by the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal and the injunction granted by the lower companyrts was accordingly Confined to roads and streets and the cleaning of public and private latrines, and the decree of the lower companyrts was set aside so far as the injunction related to the parks. play grounds, bus-stand and other public places.

facts.text: Injunction confined to roads, streets, cleaning of public and private latrines; decree set aside re parks, playgrounds, bus-stand, other public places.

anchor.surface_text: in Letters Patent Appeal and the injunction granted by the lower companyrts was accordingly Confined to roads and streets and the cleaning of public and private latrines, and the decree of the lower companyrts was set aside so far as the injunction related to the parks. play grounds, bus-stand and other public places.

facts.text: Government assigned to the House Building Society free of cost an area of about 5 acres for proposed public amenities like schools, markets etc.

anchor.surface_text: There is evidence in this case that the Government had assigned to the House Building Society free of companyt an area of about 5 acres for the proposed public amenities like schools, markets etc.

facts.text: Rules under Co-operative Societies Act required provisions for schools, markets, theatres, hospitals, clubs, religious places etc. in layout for residential colony.

anchor.surface_text: The rules framed under the Co-operative Societies Act for the formation of House Building Societies required that when an area is set apart for a residential companyony provisions for schools, markets, theatres, hospitals, clubs, religious places etc. should be made in the layout.

facts.text: There is a layout plan Ex. A-44 for Tirunagar Housing Colony.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made, on behalf of the appellant, to the layout plan Ex. A- 44 for the Tirunagar Housing companyony.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no statutory vesting in Panchayat of parks, playgrounds, schools, libraries, other public places provided by Society.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No.

facts.text: Section 56 of the Act provides that all public roads in any village vest in the panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Act reads as follows 56.  1  All public roads in any village  other than district roads and roads which are classified by the Government as national or State highways , shall vest in the panchayat together with all payments, stones and other materials thereof,

facts.text: Section 58 of the Act provides for vesting of property or income which by custom belongs to or has been administered for benefit of villagers in common.

anchor.surface_text: Section 58 is to the following effect Any property or income which by custom belongs to, or has been administered for the benefit of, the villagers in companymon, or the holders in companymon of village land generally or of lands of a particular description or of lands under a particular source of irrigation shall vest in the panchayat and be administered by it for the benefit of the villagers or holders aforesaid.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 9, 1963 of the Madras High Court in L.P.A. No. 45 of 1962. V. Narayanaswami Iyer and S. Venkatakrishnan, for the appellant.

The Society contested the suit on the ground that the constitution of the Panchayat was illegal as the provisions of the Madras Village Panchayats Act  Madras Act 10 of 1950 , hereinafter to be called the Act, had not been complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of Ramakrishnan, J. was affirmed by the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal and the injunction granted by the lower courts was accordingly Confined to roads and streets and the cleaning of public and private latrines,

issues.text: whether there is a statutory vesting in the panchayat of the parks, play grounds, schools, libraries and other public places which the Society provided for its members and whether the Panchayat is entitled to a permanent injunction restraining the Society and its servants in the manner decreed by the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether there is a statutory vesting in the panchayat of the parks, play grounds, schools, libraries and other public places which the Society provided for its members and whether the Panchayat is entitled to a permanent injunction restraining the Society and its servants in the manner decreed by the trial court.

issues.text: Whether all public roads (excluding district roads and national/State highways) vest in the panchayat under Section 56 of the Madras Village Panchayats Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Act reads as follows 56.  1  All public roads in any village  other than district roads and roads which are classified by the Government as national or State highways , shall vest in the panchayat together with all payments, stones and other materials thereof,

issues.text: Whether property or income which by custom belongs to or has been administered for the benefit of villagers in common vests in the panchayat under Section 58 of the Madras Village Panchayats Act, and whether 'by custom' qualifies both limbs.

anchor.surface_text: Section 58 is to the following effect Any property or income which by custom belongs to, or has been administered for the benefit of, the villagers in common, or the holders in common of village land generally or of lands of a particular description or of lands under a particular source of irrigation shall vest in the panchayat

issues.text: Whether parks, playgrounds or markets dedicated to the public vest in the panchayat under Section 58 of the Act without proof of custom.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted for roads under s.56; rejected for parks etc. under s.58

holdings.text: There is no statutory vesting in the panchayat of the parks, play grounds, schools, libraries and other public places which the Society provided for its members and the Panchayat is not entitled to a permanent injunction restraining the Society and its servants in the manner decreed by the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether there is a statutory vesting in the panchayat of the parks, play grounds, schools, libraries and other public places which the Society provided for its members and whether the Panchayat is entitled to a permanent injunction restraining the Society and its servants in the manner decreed by the trial court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 56 and 58 do not provide for vesting of privately provided amenities like parks without custom; affirms High Court limiting injunction to roads and latrines.

holdings.text: All public roads in any village (other than district roads and national/State highways) vest in the panchayat under Section 56 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Act reads as follows 56.  1  All public roads in any village  other than district roads and roads which are classified by the Government as national or State highways , shall vest in the panchayat together with all payments, stones and other materials thereof,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of s.56; distinguishes from other amenities; public road defined in s.2(20) as paths with public right of way.

holdings.text: The expression 'by custom' in Section 58 qualifies both 'belongs to' the villagers in common and 'has been administered for the benefit of' the villagers in common.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the grammatical structure and the context, we are of opinion that the expression by custom qualifies not only the property or income which belongs to the villagers but also property and income which has been administered for the benefit of the villagers in common.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical and contextual interpretation; s.58 covers two kinds of property only if by custom; prevents unjust vesting of private amenities.

holdings.text: Parks, playgrounds or markets dedicated to the public do not vest in the panchayat under Section 58 without proof of custom.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that if parks or play grounds or markets had been dedicated to the public the Panchayat would acquire title to such properties under s. 58 of the Act. We do not think that dedication is a relevant circumstance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dedication alone insufficient; s.58 requires proof of customary title or administration; legislature did not intend vesting merely by dedication.

holdings.text: The scope of s. 58 is confined to communal property and income which by custom belongs to or has been administered for the benefit of villagers in common and does not extend to parks, playgrounds, hospitals, libraries and schools provided by the Society.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the scope of s. 58 of the Act must be confined to communal property and income of the panchayat which by custom belongs to the villagers in common or has been administered for their benefit as a matter of custom, and the scope of that section cannot be extended to include parks,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory purpose limits to customary communal property; examples of private trusts/society amenities do not vest; avoids startling unjust results.

holdings.text: The judgment and decree of the High Court is correct and the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of statutory interpretations under ss.56/58 and affirmation of High Court's distinction between roads and other amenities.

outcome.relief_summary: Judgment and decree of the High Court affirmed; parks, playgrounds, hospitals, libraries, schools and other public places do not vest in the Panchayat under Section 58 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether there is a statutory vesting in the panchayat of the parks, play grounds, schools, libraries and other public places which the Society provided for its members and whether the Panchayat is entitled to a permanent injunction restraining the Society and its servants in the manner decreed by the trial court.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Act reads as follows 56.  1  All public roads in any village  other than district roads and roads which are classified by the Government as national or State highways , shall vest in the panchayat together with all payments, stones and other materials thereof,
For these reasons we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the grammatical structure and the context, we are of opinion that the expression by custom qualifies not only the property or income which belongs to the villagers but also property and income which has been administered for the benefit of the villagers in common.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the scope of s. 58 of the Act must be confined to communal property and income of the panchayat which by custom belongs to the villagers in common or has been administered for their benefit as a matter of custom, and the scope of that section cannot be extended to include parks,
